The website should follow academic portfolio best practices with a professional, clean design. **Required Sections:** 1. Home - Landing page with lab overview and highlights 2. About/Lab Info - Detailed information about the research lab, mission, and research areas 3. Publications - List of academic papers with citation information and download links 4. Projects - Showcase of research projects with descriptions and visuals 5. Team/Members - Profiles of lab members (PIs, postdocs, PhD students, etc.) 6. Contact - Contact information and location details **Technical Requirements:** - Static site compatible with GitHub Pages (no backend or database) - Responsive design that works seamlessly on mobile, tablet, and desktop devices - Top navigation menu that is accessible on all pages - Minimal dependencies: use plain HTML, CSS, and vanilla JavaScript - Optionally use a lightweight CSS framework (Bootstrap or Tailwind CDN) OR custom CSS - Support for Markdown-to-HTML conversion for easy content maintenance (specify the approach: manual conversion, build script, or Jekyll) - Clean, semantic HTML5 structure - Cross-browser compatibility **Content Placeholders:** - Profile photos for team members - Lab logo - Project screenshots/images - Downloadable PDF files (CVs, papers, posters) - Social media links (GitHub, Google Scholar, Twitter/X, LinkedIn) **Deliverables:** 1. Complete directory structure optimized for GitHub Pages deployment 2. All HTML files for each section 3. CSS files (either custom stylesheet or framework integration) 4. JavaScript files if needed for interactivity (mobile menu, etc.) 5. A README.md with deployment instructions 6. Placeholder images and sample content to demonstrate the layout 7. Clear instructions on how to update content (especially if using Markdown) **Design Guidelines:** - Academic and professional aesthetic - Good typography and readability - Consistent color scheme suitable for an academic institution - Proper spacing and visual hierarchy - Accessible design (WCAG guidelines) The final output should be ready to deploy by simply pushing to a GitHub repository named `username.github.io` or to a `gh-pages` branch of any Here is the summary: # Conversation Summary ## 1. Previous Conversation: The user requested creation of a complete static website for a Language Model research lab that can be deployed on GitHub Pages. The website needed to follow academic portfolio best practices with a professional, clean design. The user specified detailed requirements including: - Six sections: Home, About, Publications, Projects, Team, and Contact - Technical requirements: static site for GitHub Pages, responsive design, top navigation, minimal dependencies (plain HTML, CSS, vanilla JavaScript) - Content placeholders for images, PDFs, social links - Clean directory structure with deployment instructions ## 2. Current Work: I have been systematically building the website by: 1. Creating the directory structure: `assets/css`, `assets/js`, `assets/images/team`, `assets/images/projects`, `assets/images/logos`, `assets/files` 2. Creating a comprehensive CSS stylesheet with CSS variables, responsive design, and accessibility features 3. Creating a vanilla JavaScript file for mobile navigation and interactive elements 4. Creating all HTML pages (index.html, about.html, publications.html, projects.html, team.html) 5. **Currently working on**: Creating contact.html (was just about to start this when the summary was requested) ## 3. Key Technical Concepts: - Static site compatible with GitHub Pages (no backend) - CSS Custom Properties (variables) for theming - Mobile-first responsive design with media queries - Semantic HTML5 structure - WCAG accessibility guidelines (focus styles, ARIA attributes, screen reader support) - BEM-like CSS class naming conventions - Vanilla JavaScript for interactivity (mobile menu toggle, smooth scroll, lazy loading) - SVG icons for social media links - Academic/professional color scheme with blue theme (`--primary-color: #1a365d`) - Google Fonts integration (Inter and Playfair Display) - CSS Grid for layouts - Intersection Observer API for animations ## 4. Relevant Files and Code: - **assets/css/style.css** (905 lines) - Complete stylesheet with CSS variables, typography, navigation, hero section, buttons, cards, grid layouts, team cards, publication list, contact section, footer, page headers, and responsive breakpoints - Includes print styles and accessibility-focused styling - **assets/js/main.js** (150 lines) - Mobile menu toggle with ARIA support - Header scroll effect - Active navigation link detection - Smooth scroll for anchor links - Lazy loading images using IntersectionObserver - Scroll animations - **index.html** (261 lines) - Landing page with hero section, research areas grid, latest news, featured publications, and call-to-action - **about.html** (279 lines) - Mission statement, research areas details, values section, affiliations/partners - **publications.html** (262 lines) - Publications organized by year (2024, 2023, 2022) with PDF/arXiv/Code/BibTeX links - BibTeX copy functionality via JavaScript - **projects.html** (256 lines) - Featured ongoing projects with images and links - Completed projects section - Open source contribution call-to-action - **team.html** (284 lines) - Faculty section, Postdocs, PhD students, Alumni - Team cards with photos, roles, bios, and social links ## 5. Problem Solving: - Initial attempt to create directories using `create_directory_Filesystem` failed due to access restrictions - Resolved by using `launch-process` with `mkdir -p` command to create the directory structure successfully ## 6. Pending Tasks and Next Steps: Based on the task list, the following tasks remain: - **Create contact.html** (IN_PROGRESS) - Need to create the contact page with contact information, location details, and a map container - Will follow the same structure as other pages with header, page-header, main content, and footer - **Create placeholder images** (NOT_STARTED) - Need to generate SVG placeholders for: lab logo, favicon, team member photos (jane-smith.svg, john-doe.svg, alice-johnson.svg, bob-williams.svg, charlie-brown.svg, diana-lee.svg, eva-martinez.svg, frank-chen.svg), project images, partner logos, lab photo - **Create README.md** (NOT_STARTED) - Deployment instructions for GitHub Pages - Content update guide - Directory structure documentation - Instructions for updating publications, team members, and projects Next immediate step was to create contact.html with this structure: ```html ``` Continue the conversation and finish the task given by the user from this point.
